metadata.title: Are you guilty of using the word “experiment” incorrectly? | by Cassie Kozyrkov | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Are you guilty of using the word “experiment” incorrectly?
metadata.description: “Experiment” is a much-abused word. It has multiple meanings, so you have to listen carefully for the context. Is the word being used casually, the way little kids use it? Or is it referring to the…

all_paragraphs: “Experiment” is a much-abused word. It has multiple meanings, so you have to listen carefully for the context. Is the word being used casually, the way little kids use it? Or is it referring to the scientific gold standard for answering questions about cause-and-effect in a grown-up conversation?

When scientists use the word, it refers to the holy grail for understanding the nature of things. No wonder you’re tempted to impress everyone by telling them that you “did an experiment” too. It’s impressive! An experiment is the only legitimate* tool that gives you a license to use the word “because” in polite conversation.
An experiment gives you permission to talk about what causes what.

Consider a scientist’s emotions upon seeing a document in which you have written the word “experiment” — be still our little hearts! We’re about to unwrap a birthday present! We’re going to see what causes what!!! We’re so excited!
Can you imagine the crushing disappointment when we discover that what you have called an “experiment” is this?

As a statistician, I was trained to be precise with terminology but I’m also fairly relaxed when it comes to other people using their words incorrectly. As long as there are no dangerous consequences and we more-or-less understand one another, I don’t mind.
That’s why I’d like to take this opportunity to spend all my speak-properly-damnit coupons on this one word: experiment. Misusing it can cause lethal effects. (Especially in the era of COVID-19.)
If you have called “let’s just see what happens” an “experiment” and you’re above the age of 10, please go text-replace that word in your documents to something else.

“Chaos.” Or, if that’s too harsh, I offer you seven synonyms for “let’s just see what happens” which are far less loaded as far as science is concerned. They’re safewords, in the sense that if you say them instead of experiment, your statistician will stop hurting you.
Why would professionals put “experimental design” skills on their resumes if all it means is “let’s just see what happens?”
The first three are “study,” “investigation,” and “analysis” — you can use those for anything. When in doubt, just call everything a “study.”
The word “study” can refer to any old thing — feel free to use that word however you please.
If you want to jargon up a little bit, the technical term for “let’s just see what happens” is “observational study.”
You could also call what you’ve done a “pilot” or a “trial” if you’re okay with implying that you intend to come back and do something a little bit more rigorously designed later.
Finally, the seventh word for “let’s just see what happens” is…

If you want to use the word to refer — as children do — to a tentative procedure, then please don’t do it around people who are discussing grown-up matters like business, science, or policy. To them, an experiment is a solid, well designed, controlled attempt to understand what causes what. They’ll be referring to experiments while discussing questions like, “Does this vaccine actually work?” Questions where a misunderstanding can be extremely costly. If you’re not sure whether you’re dealing with a real experiment, avoid the word.
What is an experiment in the scientific sense and why does it carry legitimizing connotations?

An experiment is the best scientific instrument for causal reasoning by actively controlling (and eliminating) alternative explanations. If you’re about to use the word in the context of data, then make sure all of the following components are present:

A hypothesis is not enough to make a study an experiment. For example, I might have the null hypothesis that the true average height of human adults is above 3m, then I can collect data which will lead me to conclude that this null hypothesis looks ridiculous. I will be left with the scientific theory that a 10ft giant would exceed the human adult average. Yay, science! With no experiment anywhere near it!
A theory is what a hypothesis becomes when it grows up.

By the way, did you notice I used the word “theory” there? Yup, a theory is the best thing science can make. It’s what a hypothesis becomes when it grows up. (People confuse the two, thinking that a theory is something less than a hypothesis. It isn’t.)

I didn’t say “scientific fact” since that’s a quick way to reveal you have no idea how science works. Scientists don’t worship information and they’re only willing to hold on to theories until better ones come along, at which point they’ll drop that old theory like a hot potato. Meanwhile the public reverently spends the next few years continuing to burn its hands on it, “because science.”
But let’s get back on track. A hypothesis is not enough to make something an experiment, but you should have one… otherwise you won’t know how to apply treatments.
The most special thing about an experiment is that we’re not just going to observe data passively anymore. Instead, we’ll impose our will upon reality! Bwahahaha—

To do an experiment, we must make different changes to different parts of the universe. The various things we do are called treatments. (Even if the experiment has nothing to do with medicine.) A treatment where we do nothing extra is called a control. A control where we pretend to do something while actually doing nothing is called a placebo.

If there is any variability among the experimental units (objects or victims, er, I mean participants) before we begin, then it’s not a real experiment unless the units are randomly assigned to treatment groups.
Randomization plus large-enough** sample sizes is the secret sauce that makes an experiment a valid tool for causal inference.

If we have those three components, we truly have an experiment. The kind with teeth. We get the ability to talk about what causes what… even under uncertainty! This is amazing. Without experiments, all you have is correlation. Correlation is a nice way of saying “two patterns appear to move together but we’ll be laughed at if we use this to conclude that one causes the other.”

For example, if an observational study finds that people who drink red wine tend to live longer, that’s a mere correlation. No one force-fed wine to some people at random while keeping others away from it. It could be that people who are healthier/wealthier/more French/whatever live longer for some other reason and coincidentally also happen to drink more red wine. Without an experiment, there’s no evidence that red wine will make you healthier.

If you’re interested in seeing an experiment in action to understand why they work as tools for making inferences about cause-and-effect, take a look at the logic behind one of the simplest experiments you can do: the A/B test.
Treatment randomization is the secret sauce that makes an experiment tick.
If you’d like me to walk you through an explanation of A/B testing, head over to my article How do A/B tests work?
Pretty opinions are fine and dandy when there’s not much at stake, but there are a few settings in which it’s dangerous to make conclusions without experiments.

If there was no real experiment, be very skeptical of anyone using the word “because” to explain connections between complex phenomena. What that person is really saying is, “I have an opinion that sounds reasonable in my own head and I didn’t really do the homework that it takes to eliminate alternative explanations. I like my story and I’m sticking to it.”
Five examples (among many!) where I’d urge you to demand a real experiment before jumping to conclusions:

A look at the last item will remind you that sometimes it’s too difficult/expensive/unethical to carry out an experiment. Sure, sometimes we can’t afford nice things (like a license to use the word “because” instead of “I hope”).
Without an experiment, our actions are based on hope instead of evidence.

If life’s so unfair that you can’t do an experiment, that doesn’t qualify you to skip to the part where act as if you did do one anyway. Instead, admit that you’re groping around blindly in the dark and proceed with three extra heaps of caution.
If you want to say thank you, I appreciate shares and retweets. If you’re keen to read more of my writing, most of the links in this article take you to my other musings.
If you had fun here and you’re looking for an applied AI course designed to be fun for beginners and experts alike, here’s one I made for your amusement:

*Causal inference is a subfield of statistics with sophisticated attempts to make conclusions about cause-and-effect without experiments. Be advised that you’d have to be willing to swallow a mountain of assumptions to make those approaches valid, so not everyone buys into them. They also tend to rely quite heavily on the idea that “we thought of everything” which, given the beautiful fallibility of our species, is quite a stretch. Well-designed experiments that exploit randomness in large sample sizes are much more convincing.
**One day, I’ll write about power analysis and how to size an experiment, but in the meantime you can find definitions in my other articles [1] & [2].
